text: On August 20, 2007, in an attempt to convince Democrats in New Hampshire that he had the best chance of defeating the Republican candidate next year, Obama said that he could be the only candidate "to redraw the political map in fact" - especially in the south. "If we only have African-Americans in Mississippi to vote on the percentage of the population," said Mississippi, "So suddenly a democratic state." He said that the same would happen in Georgia, and that South Carolina would also be playing. His claims about those states don't stand very well for math. At the outset, Afro-Americans in Mississippi and Georgia are already close to voting on their percentage of the population. Although the proposed gains may be welcome, they will not be large enough to transform the current in these red nations. In the 2004 presidential election, 34 per cent of the electorate was black, accounting for 37 per cent of the population. The figures are similar in Georgia. In South Carolina, blacks actually made up a slightly larger proportion of the electorate on election day than they did in the population.
